posts.name:
Kriti Nigam
Kriti Nigam
posts.content:
The GENIUS way this brand made Kendall Jenner wear their clothes, for FREE.

None other than Fomo made her do this.

This is a story of a clever influencer strategy launched by an Aussie brand into the American market.

Yessss, We are talking aboutbrand strategy.

Triangl's marketing team knew they needed to make a splash in the US, but traditional influencer campaigns were too pricey.

So they got creative.

â‡‰â–¶Targeted Kendall Jenner's inner circle
â‡‰â–¶Gifted bikinis to her friends, no strings attached
â‡‰â–¶Let the FOMO effect work its magic

Soon, Kendall herself reached out, eager to get her hands on the trendy swimwear everyone was talking about.

One social media post later, Triangl had officially arrived on American shores.

Key Takeaways:

Think outside the box when funds are limited
Leverage the power of exclusivity and FOMO
Let's buzz come to you organically

By tapping into Kendall's network and creating a sense of "must-have" exclusivity, Triangl generated incredible word-of-mouth buzz.

A brilliant example of how clever, cost-effective influencer marketing can put a brand on the map

Any craziest marketing strategy you listened to?

comments.commentText: Kriti, this is a phenomenal case study on the power of creative influencer marketing. The FOMO strategy not only highlights the importance of relationship building but also showcases that sometimes unconventional approaches can lead to groundbreaking results. It's a great reminder to think differently, especially in resource-constrained environments. Thank you for sharing this insightful example!

posts.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
posts.content:
Here's how I hilariously made a complete fool of myself in Argentina. 


Upon arriving in Mendoza, I went to the ATM in the hotel to get some cash so I could tip the bell men.

I took out what I thought would be a reasonable amount for a few days. . . $10,000 Argentinian Pesos.

I walked over to the concierge feeling like a big shot and asked them to break the $1,000 bill for me.

The concierge looked at me in a funny way and asked what I meant.

I was speaking Spanish so I assume he just didn't understand me.

Upon repeating myself, he reiterated that he understood me but did not know what I was trying to accomplish.

I said I wanted to tip the bell man and need a smaller bill.

His response and tone will forever echo in my memory.

"Sir, this is the equivalent of 1 U.S. dollar."

I had taken out $10 dollars from the ATM.

Happy Friday everyone!

Yours truthfully,

posts.name:
Pranay Loya
Pranay Loya
posts.content:
The quick commerce game is heating up in India, but the real winners are the people.

has just reduced medicine delivery times to 19 minutes in Noida, Gurgaon, and Hyderabad, and 29 minutes in Kolkata, Bangalore, and Delhi!

This move could transform the healthcare ecosystem:

1ï¸âƒ£ Apollo: With 6,000+ pharmacies across India, Apollo can easily match demand and supply.
For example, a customer in Indiranagar could have their order fulfilled from one of 5 nearby stores, less than 1 km away, saving time.

2ï¸âƒ£ Customers: Quick access to medicines is critical when someone is unwell. Trust is key in healthcare, and since medicines are sourced directly from Apollo's own pharmacies, thereâ€™s no risk of duplicates or quality lapses.

3ï¸âƒ£ Delivery personnel: With high store density, delivery routes are shorter, reducing pressure on drivers and keeping safety a priority.

This efficient offline + online model ensures smooth operations.

At the end of the day when every second counts, faster care isnâ€™t just convenienceâ€”itâ€™s life-saving!

posts.name:
Jake Dunlap
Jake Dunlap
posts.content:
If you are 25, stop sending gif of people breaking up to a 50 year old and send something with customized value

If you are a seasoned 20 year vet, stop sending a novel follow up and send a 1.5 minute video to your 35 year old champion

About 1% of VPs I talk to are active on TikTok

About 90% of Gen Z people are active on TikTok

As a seller, you don't get to choose what type of medium or type of message to send...it's your job to match the way the CUSTOMER wants to consume

To be clear and I'm not saying every Gen Z likes video and everyone 45-60 year olds hate Tiktok

Not every Gen Z wants bite-sized content. Not every millennial needs a detailed white paper. Even a baby boomer might want concise, actionable takeaways they can skim between meetings

Iâ€™m not saying to fall into generational stereotypes. The goal is to be intentional. Figure out how each person wants to engage and meet them there

BUT....I am 100% saying that you do NOT get to pick how to communicate to buyers. The buyer gets to pick how they want to receive communication and we have to adapt

comments.commentText: Speaking of good content, I love your video clips. (I must be in the right generation, ha!) Are you using any special software to make these?
customizing communication is key in todayâ€™s diverse world. what can we do next?
